mainContentArray.text: One of the three Dwarven brothers who rediscovered the Wave Echo Cave.

mainContentArray.title: History:
mainContentArray.text: Brother of Tharden Rockseeker, and of Nundro Rockseeker. He was also a friend to Sildar Hallwinter, a member of the Lords' Alliance. The dwarf and his brothers located Wave Echo Cave, the legendary home of the Forge of Spells. He excitedly rushed back to Neverwinter to gather supplies and gear, and hire a party of adventurers to haul the equipment to Phandalin.
The youngest of the three dwarf brothers who rediscovered Wave Echo Cave.
The eldest of the three dwarf brothers who rediscovered Wave Echo Cave.

geographyDetails.location: Sword Coast, between the Sword Montains and Neverwinter Woods

mainContentArray.text: Phandalin was a village in the Sword Coast North that enjoyed much prosperity in the 10th century DR, as it was the closest settlement to the Wave Echo Cave. It was raided by orcs in 961 DR and subsequently abandoned.

mainContentArray.title: Re-settlement:
mainContentArray.text: Phandalin is a modest and architecturally boring town of hard-working frontiersfolk built atop the ruins of the old Phandalin. The town quickly grew to about fifty well-maintained structures built of logs and flagstones with three deep wells providing water. The town is dominated by an apple orchard on the west side and a ruined manor atop a hill to the east. The townsfolk congregate in a small town square and an adjacent town green.

When Phandalin was reestablished in the late 15th century DR, at first it had no real functioning government, and the Phandalin Miner's Exchange began acting as a center of records-keeping for local mining claims. The townsfolk also annually elected a 'Townmaster' who served as a judge and mediator as well as kept town records. In 1491 DR, Harbin Wester was the perennial Townmaster.

A commercial agreement between the human settlers of Phandalin and the gnomes and dwarves of Wave Echo Cave, established to exploit the natural resources and magical potential of the cave. The association was disbanded when the cave was overrun by orcs in 951 DR. The pact was named after the town of Phandalin, which was the closest settlement to the mine.

mainContentArray.title: History:
mainContentArray.text: In the 10th century DR, clans of dwarves and gnomes made a pact that would later be known as Phandelver's Pact. The pact allowed both of the races to share the riches within the mine of Wave Echo Cave. Many gained from this agreement, including the nearby human settlement of Phandalin.

When it was discovered that the cavern had wondrous magical properties, spellcasters from Phandalin allied themselves with the dwarves and gnomes to harness this magical power and use it to its fullest potential. They bound the magic into a forge they called the Forge of Spells, where they crafted magical weapons and other items.

However, in 951 DR, the orcs of Uruth Ukrypt came from the north and laid waste to the region. The orcs were aided by mercenary wizards when they attacked Wave Echo Cave, adamant in seizing its riches. The human spellcasters of Phandalin fought alongside the gnomes and dwarves to defend the cave. However, the battle of magic destroyed much of Wave Echo Cave. Few survived the battle and so the location of the cave was lost to history.

Sildar is a sellsword and a respected member of the Lords' Alliance. He set off to Phandalin from Neverwinter to escort Gundren Rockseeker, who had recently rediscovered the Wave Echo Cave. Sildar had his own reasons for visiting Phandalin, and wished to find out what was happening with his fellow agent of the Lords' Alliance, Iarno Albrek, with whom he lost contact. He also wanted to help Gundren and his brothers re-open the mine, as well as establish Phandalin as a place of prosperity, as it once was.

Wave Echo Cave was a great cavern complex within the northern Sword Mountains and the location of the Forge of Spells. It is located somewhere south of Phandalin, within the range's deep vales. The cavern was known for its mineral wealth—notably mithril and platinum—as well as its magical properties.

mainContentArray.title: History:
mainContentArray.text: In the 10th century DR, clans of dwarves and gnomes made a pact that would later be known as Phandelver's Pact (see related article). The pact allowed both of the races to share the riches within the mine of Wave Echo Cave. Many gained from this agreement, including the nearby human settlement of Phandalin. The location of the cave was lost to time after it was overrun by orcs in 951 DR, and it has been a regional attraction for would-be archeologists.

Iarno Albrek is a human wizard and a member of the Lords' Alliance. He was sent to Phandalin to establish order in the region. He was also tasked with finding out what happened to the Forge of Spells, and to make sure that the mine was reopened.
The Lords' Alliance is a coalition of rulers from cities and towns across Faerûn (primarily in the North), who collectively agree that some solidarity is needed to keep evil at bay.

The rulers of Waterdeep, Silverymoon, Neverwinter, and other free cities in the region dominate the Alliance, and every lord in the Alliance works for the fate and fortune of his or her own settlement above all others. The agents of the Alliance include sophisticated bards, zealous paladins, talented mages, and grizzled warriors. They are chosen primarily for their loyalty, and are trained to work as spies, diplomats, and warriors.
Known to the ancient dwarves as Glaurimm, was a volcano amid the Crags mountain range, situated to the northeast of the city of Neverwinter on the Sword Coast North, deep in Neverwinter Wood.

mainContentArray.title: Description:
mainContentArray.text: It was home to a large population of fire elementals, warming the Neverwinter River to the point where it never froze over, even in the heart of winter, giving the city its name. After its eruption (see related article), Mount Hotenow looked like a set of serrated teeth many described as a 'door to the Nine Hells' (or the Elemental Chaos, according to others).

Within Mount Hotenow were largely untapped deposits of alum, nitre, and sal ammoniac. Following the eruption, deposits of rare black diamonds were found in the crater's rim. The volcano also had a tendency to attract creatures like fire giants and red dragons to make their homes near it.

Neverwinter, also known as the City of Skilled Hands and the Jewel of the North, was a multi-racial city-state sitting on the northwestern Sword Coast of Faerûn. The city was a member in good standing of the Lords' Alliance.

mainContentArray.title: Description:
mainContentArray.text: The city was so named because, even in winter, the Neverwinter River that flows through it never froze. The city proper was built on the right bank of the river, and the city's walls were punctuated by eight gates. The city was divided into several districts, including the Protector's Enclave, the Blacklake District, the River District, and the Tower District.

The city was known for its many craftsmen, and was considered one of the most cosmopolitan and civilized cities in all of Faerûn. The city was also known for its many festivals, including the annual Wintershield festival.

mainContentArray.title: Geography:
mainContentArray.text: Neverwinter stood on the northern Sword Coast, on the High Road between Waterdeep and Luskan. To the east lay the Neverwinter Wood and, at its heart, the volcanic Mount Hotenow.

The Neverwinter River was heated by fire elementals living under the volcano before flowing through the forest and the city. It carried its supernatural warmth with it, keeping the river and harbor from freezing up in winter and the gardens green year-round. The heat given off by the river created a permanent warm climate in the immediate area.

Thundertree was a small village located in the Neverwinter Wood, just north of the city of Neverwinter. The village was abandoned after the eruption of Mount Hotenow, which caused widespread destruction in the area.

eventDetails.impact: Regional, destruction of Thundertree, heavy damage on Neverwinter

mainContentArray.text: The eruption of Mount Hotenow was a catastrophic event that occurred in 1451 DR. The eruption caused widespread destruction in the area, including the destruction of the village of Thundertree and heavy damage to the city of Neverwinter.

mainContentArray.title: Description:
mainContentArray.text: In 1451 DR, a small adventuring party rediscovered the ancient dwarven city of Gauntlgrym beneath the volcano. The party, consisting of Dahlia Sin'felle, Korvin Dor'crae, Valindra Shadowmantle, Athrogate, and Jarlaxle Baenre, made it all the way to the legendary forges. There, the latter two were betrayed by their Thayan allies, with Athrogate hypnotically forced to activate the forge.

This briefly awoke the primordial Maegera, who, in a fit of rage, released a burst of energy so powerful that it forced the eruption of the volcano. The resulting earthquake and combination of smoke and lava destroyed much of Neverwinter, killing thousands. The eruption entirely destroyed the settlement of Thundertree.

geographyDetails.location: Sword Coast, between Neverwinter and Waterdeep

mainContentArray.text: A small town that was once a prosperous port on the Sword Coast. It was abandoned after the Spellplague, and it's currently being rebuilt.

A mining town that sold copper, nickel, and silver to Waterdeep. It was also a port where merchants sometimes offloaded goods on barges (since most ships cannot pass the town's shallow mud flats) to be transferred to cities along the Sword Coast.

Two hundred years ago, the wizard Thalivar made his home here and raised a tower at the town center to conduct his mystical studies. The House of Thalivar was topped with a planar beacon that lured creatures from other planes into the structure, trapping them there. After Thalivar mysteriously disappeared, the people of Leilon were content to leave his tower and the monsters within alone. The Spellplague, a divine phenomenon that twisted Faerûn's magic, corrupted the tower's defenses. The creatures sealed within were freed to attack Leilon, and the magic of the planar beacon was redirected back into the Material Plane, causing humanoids who looked upon it to become paralyzed. Leilon was quickly overrun and subsequently abandoned and has remained that way for more than a century.

The first action the soldiery of Neverwinter took in Leilon was to destroy the planar beacon inside the House of Thalivar. A talented mage, has rebuilt it to perform his own studies into the Ethereal Plane. Before its fall, Leilon was defended by a loosely organized group of adventurers called the Swords of Leilon. When the House of Thalivar released its monsters, the Swords fought to cover the escape of the townsfolk. They died, becoming ghosts bound to Leilon's ruins. They now watch the rebuilding of the town with caution, hoping that the reconstructed tower does not bring similar disaster.

eventDetails.impact: Universal, temporal destruction of the Weave

mainContentArray.text: The Spellplague was a magical catastrophe that struck all the planes of existance. The most widely accepted theory proposes the event was a direct result of the death of the goddess Mystra, the goddess of magic, which caused the Weave, the source of all magic, to unravel.

mainContentArray.title: Cause:
mainContentArray.text: The most popular and widely accepted theory about the origins of the Spellplague was that this calamity was caused by the death of Mystra, the goddess of Magic. For eons, magic had been bound within Mystra's Weave, the universal structure of arcane forces, and her death tore the Weave apart and unleashed the raw magic contained within it, creating the cataclysm that was later known as the Spellplague.

Other scholars, however, didn't consider this to be a logical explanation. Historically, two earlier incarnations of Mystra had died before only to be reborn, and the Weave maintained its hold over the power of magic for the duration of her deaths. In these scholars' views, the truth would never be fully known to mortals, and perhaps not even to the gods.

mainContentArray.title: Effects:
mainContentArray.text: Whatever its cause, the Weave collapsed and, without the Weave, the Shadow Weave was unable to be maintained and collapsed as well. The breakdown of the Weave was felt by all wizards across Faerûn. The corrupted madness of Cyric defiled what arcane forces remained from the dissolution of the Weave, resulting in a new magical source of defiling arcane energy in the form of blue flames that destroyed Dweomerheart and continued to spread across the multiverse.

Anything that came into contact with the Spellplague risked being destroyed or warped by its energies. Creatures and individuals risked becoming 'plaguechanged', which entailed massive physical mutations and often a complete loss of sanity, and sometimes bestowed the creature or individual with terrible powers. Those who came into contact with weaker versions of the Spellplague were sometimes lucky enough to escape with only a spellscar, which could also bestow potent magical abilities. Physical places could also be horribly warped by the Spellplague, becoming a changeland.
